caption_original: The Ottawa River should be a place where Canadians can swim, drink and fish. Environment and Climate Change Minister Catherine McKenna announced an upcoming study on the potential creation of an Ottawa RiverWatershed Council. The study will include an analysis of indicators, such as water quality, biodiversity, and shoreline integrity, as well as an assessment of the economic, cultural, heritage, and natural values within the Ottawa River watershed.

caption_original:
Fact or fiction? A tree is a safe hiding place from lightning. When thunder roars GO, INDOORS! 

Fiction: No, in fact standing under a tree is one of the most dangerous places to be during a thunderstorm. Lightning can strike a tree and the current can travel down the trunk and exit two ways: it can side flash from mid-trunk and jump out and hit you. Or, the lightning can flow out through the roots and you can be hit by ground current. If you are in a forested area during a storm, stay on the trail, not near a tree, and keep everyone a few metres apart from each other. http://ow.ly/hl2N30cCX9D
caption_cleaned: Fact or fiction? A tree is a safe hiding place from lightning. When thunder roars GO, INDOORS! Fiction: No, in fact standing under a tree is one of the most dangerous places to be during a thunderstorm. Lightning can strike a tree and the current can travel down the trunk and exit two ways: it can side flash from mid-trunk and jump out and hit you. Or, the lightning can flow out through the roots and you can be hit by ground current. If you are in a forested area during a storm, stay on the trail, not near a tree, and keep everyone a few metres apart from each other. 9D

caption_original:
Pointe-au-P√®re National Wildlife Area is one of the best shorebird-watching sites in Quebec. In the spring, flocks of Least Sandpipers congregate at the site, while Great Blue Heron feed in the marshes in the company of Black-crowned Night-herons and large communities of Brants. 

In the summer, American Black Ducks, Mallards, Northern Pintails and Green-winged Teals raise their young and feed on the plentiful invertebrates in the brackish ponds. During the fall migration, Red-throated Loon and Common Loon, and large numbers of Canada Geese, are observed. Large communities of Sanderlings and Semipalmated Sandpipers also use the area, along with the White-rumped Sandpiper. http://ow.ly/plvi30cG7YS #BirdYear #Canada150
caption_cleaned: Pointe-au-P√®re National Wildlife Area is one of the best shorebird-watching sites in Quebec. In the spring, flocks of Least Sandpipers congregate at the site, while Great Blue Heron feed in the marshes in the company of Black-crowned Night-herons and large communities of Brants. In the summer, American Black Ducks, Mallards, Northern Pintails and Green-winged Teals raise their young and feed on the plentiful invertebrates in the brackish ponds. During the fall migration, Red-throated Loon and Common Loon, and large numbers of Canada Geese, are observed. Large communities of Sanderlings and Semipalmated Sandpipers also use the area, along with the White-rumped Sandpiper.

caption_original: Cap Tourmente National Wildlife Area offers contrasting landscapes shaped by the meeting of the St. Lawrence river, large coastal marshes, plains and mountains. The wildlife area is home to more than 180 bird species, 30 mammal species, 22 types of forest stands and 700 plant species. Many of these species are at risk, including the Peregrine Falcon, the Bobolink, and the Butternut. #Canada150 http://ow.ly/EWmM30cCnHR

caption_original: Have you heard about the #Canada150 insect? Known formally as the Apimela canadensis, this tiny beetle was discovered in eastern Canada in 2008. In 2017, it joins the ranks as an official insect. Find out how #NRCanSci contributed to this exciting discovery!
